name: Genoa
fun_fact: Fun fact: Genoa is the birthplace of both Christopher Columbus AND pesto! The city's Genovese basil has DOP protection - only basil grown in Genoa's specific soil and climate can be used in authentic pesto alla genovese. The city also has 42 UNESCO-listed Renaissance palaces that once hosted state guests on rotation!

hero_dishes.name: Pesto alla Genovese
hero_dishes.description: The original pesto, DOP-protected and made with 7 specific ingredients: PDO Genovese basil, Ligurian extra virgin olive oil, PDO Parmigiano Reggiano, PDO Pecorino Sardo, pine nuts, garlic, and salt
hero_dishes.origin_story: First written recipe appeared in 1852 in 'La Cuciniera Genovese' by Emanuele Rossi. The name comes from 'pestÃ¢' (to pound) - traditionally made in a marble mortar with wooden pestle. The Genovese basil's unique flavor is impossible to replicate elsewhere due to Genoa's specific soil and climate. Working toward UNESCO recognition alongside Neapolitan pizza!
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditionally served with mandilli de sÃ¦a ('silk handkerchiefs'), trofie, or trenette pasta throughout Genoa. Watch for the World Championship of Pesto with Mortar held annually since 2007

hero_dishes.name: Focaccia di Recco
hero_dishes.description: Ultra-thin, yeast-free focaccia filled with stracchino cheese, awarded IGP (Protected Geographical Indication) status. Two impossibly thin sheets of dough with oozing melted cheese
hero_dishes.origin_story: Dates to 12th century, mentioned in documents about food Ligurian crusaders brought to the Holy Land. Legend says it originated when locals fled Saracen pirates inland and made this 'poor food' with what they found. Only officially made in 4 towns: Recco, Avegno, Camogli, and Sori
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Manuelina in Recco - considered the birthplace and most authentic version. An anomaly among Ligurian focaccias due to absence of yeast

hero_dishes.name: Farinata
hero_dishes.description: Giant chickpea flour pancake baked in copper pans in wood-fired ovens, made with just chickpea flour, water, olive oil, and salt
hero_dishes.origin_story: Dates to 1447 when a Republic of Genoa decree regulated oil quality for farinata. Spread to South America - called 'fainÃ ' in Argentina, just like the Genoese dialect. Best eaten at traditional sciamadde (old shops with wood ovens, white tile walls, marble counters)
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Antica Sciamadda in Genoa - renowned for perfectly baked farinata served hot from wood ovens. Look for authentic sciamadde throughout the city

hero_dishes.name: Corzetti (Croxetti) Pasta
hero_dishes.description: Unique round pasta stamped with designs, dating to Middle Ages when noble families stamped their coats of arms onto the pasta
hero_dishes.origin_story: Medieval tradition from eastern Liguria around Genoa and La Spezia, using unique wooden stamps to create decorative patterns
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional restaurants in Genoa's historic center, often served with walnut sauce

signature_drinks.name: Ligurian Wine
signature_drinks.description: Local wines from the Ligurian Riviera coastal vineyards
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Paired with pesto and seafood dishes at traditional Genoese restaurants

signature_drinks.name: Italian Espresso

signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Quick at the bar, standing, as locals do throughout Italy

food_culture_notes: Pesto alla Genovese has DOP protection - strict ingredient requirements enforced
The Pesto Genovese Consortium protects the official recipe and traditions
Genoa has one of Europe's largest and densest medieval centers (113 hectares)
During Rolli Days (bi-annual festival), 42 UNESCO palazzi open to the public
Traditional sciamadde shops maintain wood-fired ovens for authentic farinata
Recco is also famous for pansotti pasta with walnut sauce and trofiette with pesto

landmarks: Palazzi dei Rolli (42 UNESCO-listed Renaissance palaces)
Via Garibaldi (Strade Nuove) - first European planned urban development
Medieval caruggi (narrow alleys opening to small squares)
Palazzo Rosso, Palazzo Bianco, Palazzo Doria-Tursi museums
atmosphere: Birthplace of Christopher Columbus, Paganini, Mazzini, Renzo Piano
3-4 story palaces with spectacular staircases, courtyards, gardens
unique_modern: World Championship of Pesto with Mortar (since 2007)
Pesto seeking UNESCO cultural heritage status
Il Cannone - Paganini's famous violin at Palazzo Doria-Tursi
